substrateUtilizationMethod: Partially extend one telescopic section so it rests loosely (unlocked). Lay the stick horizontally with the loosened section pointing toward you. Chop downward onto that section. The aluminium tube first resists; when the impact force exceeds static friction the segment slides inward with a quick clack, giving a pronounced release analogous to wood fibres snapping.

contactUtilizationMethod: Wrap your hand firmly around the cardboard tube as though it were the wooden handle. Though light, the diameter and length encourage a full power grip and allow rehearsal of the shoulder-led swing path and wrist snap that would drive a virtual axe.

physicalSubstrateObject: grey and white camouflage-patterned video game controller
substrateUtilizationMethod: Place the controller upside-down so one of its trigger buttons faces straight up. Drive the cardboard tube onto that trigger. The spring in the trigger builds resistance and then produces a loud click and swift bottom-out, delivering the same build-and-break sensation of the axe finally cleaving wood.

substrateUtilizationMethod: Drop the loosely coiled cable on a table so it forms a small circular pile. Bring the tube straight into the centre of the coil. The rubbery loops compress and fight the motion (tension). As your tube sinks, the loops suddenly slide apart and spring outward, removing resistance in an instant—mirroring the clean split of chopped firewood.
